Explanation: The doctor suggested Cognitive Testing, which aligns with the purpose of the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) to assess cognitive function.
The doctor suggested Brain Imaging (MRI or CT Scan) to rule out structural abnormalities in the brain, which aligns with the justification for ruling out structural causes of dementia.
The doctor did not specifically suggest 'Thyroid function tests' or any investigation with a justification directly related to excluding hypothyroidism as a reversible cause of cognitive impairment.
The doctor suggested Blood Tests to check for underlying medical conditions, which can include vitamin deficiencies like Vitamin B12, thus aligning with the justification provided.
The doctor did not suggest a Complete Blood Count (CBC) or any investigation with a similar justification related to ruling out anemia or infection.
The doctor did not suggest an electrolyte panel or any investigation with a similar justification related to identifying imbalances affecting cognitive function.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations related to liver function tests or hepatic encephalopathy.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations specifically related to serum glucose levels or similar justifications for checking hypoglycemia or diabetes.
The doctor did not suggest any investigations specifically aimed at screening for depression, which is necessary to rule out its contribution to cognitive impairment.
The doctor did not suggest an EEG or any investigation specifically aimed at ruling out seizure activity as a cause of confusion and memory loss.
